Award.AwardTitle: Comparative Histories of Scientific Conservation: Nature, Science, and Society in Patagonian and Amazonian South America

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
Introduction

South American nations were among the first to create parks; they protect the highest number of large reserves, and they retain the highest percentage of protected areas with people living inside. But little comparative work has contextualized their initial declaration, their evolution, or their societal meaning. As a result, generalizations are being made about parks globally that overlook the role of scientists in transforming the landscape. This project asks how the development of natural field sciences has led to the establishment, maintenance, and promotion of national parks in Amazonia and Patagonia.

Intellectual Merit

This research merges a history of science approach to understanding technical research with environmental history's insights into social, political, and cultural influences within and across societies. As a comparative study, it will use the long twentieth century (1870s to present) to chart the contours of scientifically-informed conservation through attention to six park groups in Argentina, Brazil, Chile, and Peru. The project methodology involves document analysis of archival sources (such as exploration journals, research station records, published studies, and correspondence) as well as oral histories of scientists and social groups interacting with scientists. Abundant literature on conservation exists in disciplines like conservation biology, geography, anthropology, and political science but few studies give the comparative perspective of time and place. Careful historical research will bridge current debates in these disciplines by contextualizing the competing systems of knowledge and scientific traditions.

Potential Broader Impacts

Despite their seemingly benign presence, national parks have a contested history. That history explains much about how science becomes policy, how scientific understandings shape the landscape, and how global networks of scientific knowledge have influenced the protection of nature. Understanding the past with greater clarity will provide a better framework for understanding the role of science in shaping conservation policies. The results of this project will be disseminated in multiple ways (a book, a teaching website, and an international symposium) to enhance the prospects for having these impacts.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award has supported research into the relationship between science and conservation. Many foundational concepts of the field sciences, from Darwin to biodiversity, were derived from research in Amazonian or Patagonian South America. In turn, South American nations have created parks and reserves such that conservation occupies nearly twenty percent of the continent. This project investigated the relationship between these two processes for the comparative perspective it provides. Fierce debates exist about conservation and national parks but we hardly have a comprehensive picture of how national parks came to be included as public resources around the world. The findings include the insight that national parks are unevenly distributed but particularly stable entities whose scale and spread rivals other more conventional forms of state-making such as land reform, agricultural development, and roads.  Parks have been formed at the initiative of or in consultation with scientists and have resulted in the translation of technical scientific terms, such as biodiversity, into popular discourse. The study also reveals how conservation takes place in a middle space between customary land uses and scientific principles.  This research has advanced the way we think about the resonance of scientific theories in conservation policy. The interplay between science and policy matters to global concerns over conservation.

This grant provided the time and resources needed to collect the archival and oral history sources (the foundation of any historical study) on which this study is based. This included investigation by the PI in twenty-nine separate archives across six countries (Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Germany, Peru and the United States). The PI developed a database with more than 1300 primary and secondary sources from these investigations.  The PI also conducted twenty oral histories with scientists and conservationists with six still pending. 

This extensive research base has resulted in five major activities.  The first major impact of this award is the dissemination of findings in the writing of scholarly papers and a book. The book contains five main arguments. First, the research shows that there were two major periods for scientific conservation, the 1930s in Patagonia and the 1970s in Amazonia.  These bursts of time represented significant changes to the orientation, extent, and organization of national parks such that they created two separate paradigms--one based on aesthetics and the other based on scientific theories. Second, this research shows that conservation takes place in a middle space between customary uses and scientific principles that opens up new avenues of experience and of expertise.  Because of the space afforded to conservation, a new class of people could begin to make their lives out of conservation work. Third, this research demonstrates that by looking at ecological and cultural regions--rather than just nation-states--a more synthetic picture of conservation emerges.  This picture shows that the Latin American story of conservation is quite distinct from the African, Asian, European, or North American story. Fourth, scientific theories have a resonance in conservation policy that makes theory and scientific practice relevant to the history of national parks.  This is to say, theories create footprints and these footprints make tracks into people's lives--whether they are park rangers, biodiversity specialists, or agriculturalists.
